content.question: Students in the lab construct the mass-spring oscillator shown in the figure, using a single spring and attaching objects with different masses. They collect the data in the table. Which of the following graphs has the correct best-fit line and can best be used to determine the spring constant of the spring?

choices.label: The figure presents a scatterplot with a line of best fit drawn in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled, m, in kilograms and the numbers 0 through 0.3, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled T, in seconds and the numbers 0 through 0.3, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. There are 4 data points on the graph, which are as follows. Note all values are approximate. Point 1: 0.1 kilogram comma 0.14 second. Point 2: 0.15 kilogram comma 0.20 second. Point 3: 0.2 kilogram comma 0.23 second. Point 4: 0.25 kilogram comma 0.25 kilogram comma 0.25 second. A straight line moving upward and to the right is drawn from a point with coordinates 0.07 kilogram comma 0.07 second to a point at 2.2 kilogram comma 0.3 second.

The figure presents a scatterplot with a line of best fit drawn in a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled, m, in kilograms and the numbers 0 through 0.3, in increments of 0.1, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled T squared, in 10 to the negative 2 power, seconds squared and the numbers 0 through 6, in increments of 2, are indicated. There are 4 data points on the graph, which are as follows. Note all values are approximate. Point 1: 0.1 kilogram comma 1.9 times 10 to the negative 2 power seconds squared. Point 2: 0.15 kilogram comma 3.8 times 10 to the negative 2 power seconds squared. Point 3: 0.2 kilogram comma 5.3 times 10 to the negative 2 power seconds squared. Point 4: 0.25 kilogram comma 6.2 times 10 to the negative 2 power seconds squared. A straight line moving upward and to the right is drawn from a point with coordinates 0.07 kilogram comma 1.0 times 10 to the negative 2 power seconds squared to a point at 0.26 kilogram comma 6.8 times 10 to the negative 2 power seconds squared.
